title: Wednesday, 2nd March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE

BE

Portrait wise, I guess we need to look across the pond.

BE

Seems we're in a bit of a fight between the likelihood of ECB loosening next week and the realities of pretty rubbish results.

First though, Burberry.

11:11 am
Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,381, up 29 (+2.14%), High: 1,400, Low: 1,355, Volume: 1.11m

11:14 am

BE

BE

Or .... well, there's been all sorts of talk recently about luxury goods consolidation.

11:16 am

(One of my daughters is in the fine jewellery trade. Trust me, it's fallen off a cliff since the turn of the year.)

11:18 am
BE

Yeah, I don't entirely get this Burberry rally and, as I say, it's all extremely vague rumour rather than anything specific.

BE

But if we go back to the Nomura note from last week, it does point out that Burberry carries very little debt.

BE

Because of the way it accounts for leases, which might seem over cautious.

11:20 am

Perhaps there's an LBO story here? I dunno. I reiterate, I don't know what the story is. But there seems to be a story. So I note it.

undefined

We have Entertainment One.

Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 151.70, down 21.3 (-12.31%), High: 170.90, Low: 150.50, Volume: 1.18m

http://www.investe...1603020700097138Q/

http://uk.eonefilm...-a737-69ef6c0aec5a

11:21 am
PM

oops

BE

Okay. So here's what happened.

BE

Cazenove predicted on February 24 that -- finally! -- E1 was going to take a sensible approach to spending.

11:22 am
BE

As in, it'd start spending less than it makes.

BE

"we expect FY16 results (end March 16) to be the tipping point for cash conversion (JPMe 55% in FY16, vs. 38% in FY15) and remain buyers into the upcoming 9M15 trading statement (likely first week of March)," said Caz.

BE

Turns out, not so much.

11:22 am
BE

Because while the headline figures from E1 look okay, it's full of stuff like .....

BE

The Mark Gordon Company has over 50 active TV projects in development

BE

As in, it intends to keep spending more than it makes.

11:23 am
BE

Burning the Peppa Pig revenue on 500 hours of TV and circa 210 film releases

BE

And while there's a bit of restructuring of the film unit, it's to save £10m ...... by 2018

BE

Which is about equivalent to the budget of Christmas With the Coopers

11:23 am
BE

BE

(Metacritic rating: 31% on ‎26 reviews)

PM

oh please

11:23 am
BE

Here's Caz's mea culpa

BE

Entertainment One released its 9M16 trading update this morning.
Overall, the performance was similar to H116 with a weak Film business
(down -14% y/y) almost fully offset by a continuously strong TV division
(+39% y/y). Management commented that it expects FY earnings to be in line
with current consensus expectations and FY16 FCF (after interest/tax) to turn
positive. However, management also flagged 50 active TV projects within the
Marc Gordon Company and in 2017 we see rising investment spend limiting
the potential for positive FCF generation. While our 2016 EPS estimate
remains unchanged at 19.8p, our 2017E EPS changes slightly by -2.3% from
20.6p to 20.1p (due to minorities/tax). Our updated estimates put us +1%/0%
ahead of (in our view conservative) consensus expectations of 19.6p/20.1p.
The shares are trading on 8.7x/8.6x 16E/17E P/E.

BE

 The business continues to show a mixed performance with weak Film
revenues offset by continuously strong growth in TV. Television
revenues increased +39% y/y driven by strong international sales and a
strong performance of Family (Peppa Pig). Management commented that
679 half hours of content have been produced/acquired and reiterated
guidance for 1,000 half hours for FY16. Also, sales in the US were
particularly strong for the Family business with licensing partners having
doubled in cal. 2015. In contrast, Film revenues (down -14%) continue to
remain weak given lower film releases (the company reiterated its recent
guidance for 210 film releases in 2016). Further efficiency measures in the
division are expected to generate £10m of annualized savings by FY18.

11:24 am
BE

 Management is guiding for positive FCF (after tax/interest) in 2016
which is clearly encouraging. However, we believe rising investments
(particular for new projects within the Marc Gordon company) will
negatively impact FCF in 2017. We have increased our 2017E investments
in production from £375m to £475m and forecast +£26m/£-11m/+£27m of
Equity FCF in 2016E/2017E/2018E. We assume FY16 net debt of c.£170m
(ex production ND, £267m incl production ND) and financial leverage of
1.3x (versus management guidance for 1.4x leverage). The compares to
FY2015 net debt of £225m.

BE

And Peel Hunt, which downgrades.

BE

Overall trading is in line with the company’s expectations.
Within this stable outlook is a weak film performance
(prompting a reorganisation process and cost in FY2017) offset
by good TV and acquisition benefits. We will leave EPS for FY
2016/2017 largely unchanged (note we include share option
charge within this). But debt (bond plus IPF less cash) will rise to
£300m by the year end (vs £260m previously, PHe) and will hit
£330m in 2017. The P/L interest charge will rise to c£24m in
2017 on net senior debt of £140m − with IPF funding being
capitalised. The shares having rallied hard in advance of the
update today, but now stand on 9.8x PER. We move to Add
from Buy, with an unchanged 200p target price.

11:30 am
BE

While in media I guess we need to mention ITV.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 241.20, down 8.4 (-3.37%), High: 251.70, Low: 239.70, Volume: 13.81m
PM

(David McWilliams has just joined us here in the office. I was so absorbed in that earlier legal stuff that I forgot he was coming in. embarassed smile )

11:30 am
PM

But if you have any questions for David, pitch 'em and I will pitch him.)

BE

ITV beats, does the special that was predicted and keeps guidance the same. Shares down 3.3%.

PM

Tough reaction

11:31 am
PM

Is there a proper explanation?

PM

Outlook a bit muddy?

BE

Well, not really. ITV Family viewing figures are down, but we knew they would be.

11:33 am
PM

Aviate still buyers i see

PM

The solid FY15 numbers and special dividend are well flagged but the NAR commentary will weigh on the stock short term. We would buy that weakness. . National Advertising Revenue, or NAR is to be flat in Q1, marginally behind the market and against 12% growth in Q1 last year. This versus industry growth of 2-3%, so optically disappointing. However, it's mostly due to phasing; Q2 improves and will benefit from the Euros and they expect outperform the TV ad market for the FY. ITV Studios continues to impress with organic revenue growth of +8% (with US an impressive +15%) and EBITA +27% in FY15. Add in the BBC decision (see below) and the potential M&A optionality for one of the large media multinationals at a time of extreme Sterling weakness and we see favourable risk/reward. It’s still a genuine compounder, with high CROIC which is growing. With regard to the BBC, the recommendation is for the BBC Trust to be scrapped and that Ofcom (headed by Sharon White who was credited with helping Osborne get through the “political dog that did not bark” public spending cuts during the coalition days). All measures to curtail the power of the BBC can only reinforce the relative strength of rival ITV in the UK market. Buy weakness.

PM

Investec are on hold

11:33 am
PM

They dont like the outlook

PM

FY15 figs are 2% above forecast at EPS level mainly due to better broadcast margin. The outlook for 1Q is worse than we expected (and we had already cut) so bad for the bulls, but the special dividend of 10p/share (£400m) is positive - while not in our numbers, this was widely anticipated however. We remain at Hold – persistent take-over speculation in the media and retransmission fees imply some support though we see mid-term TV structural challenges and ITV specific issues e.g. slowing NAR, consistent SOCI pressure, peak commissioning performance and management changes.

PM

Steve Liechti

11:34 am
PM

Outlook – 1Q Family NAR is expected flat (below market) so below our downgraded +2.5% but 2Q should be better (Euro football). We need to check ITV FY comment, but the bulls should be disappointed. We f/c FY16E +2.9% LFL - by quarter +2.5%+6%-3%/+6%. Share of viewing is up ytd (Family +2%). ITV Studios is expected to deliver double digit sales/profit growth – we have sales +11% and profit +13%.
Forecasts under review – base EPS is 2% higher, but much will depend on detailed ITV commentary on FY broadcast prospects.
Valuation – CY16E EV/EBITDA 10.5x, P/E 14x and FCF/div yield 5.1%/2.9%.
FY15 external sales £2972m (+15%) vs forecast £2949m with adj EBITA £865m vs f/c £857m at 29% margin (28.2%) as f/c. Adj PBT £843m (+18%) vs f/c £831m. Basic adj EPS 16.5p (+20%) vs f/c 16.2p (table below shows FD EPS) and dividend 6p (+28%), as f/c, but with a new special div of 10p.
Broadcast/online – sales £2146m (+6%) vs f/c £2136m with NAR +6% as f/c and as 9M. Share of viewing for Family is -3% and SOCI -4% - this compares to -3% for both at 10M. Online/interactive sales are £188m (+23%) vs f/c £184m. Adj EBITA £659m vs f/c £649m at better 30.7% margin (28.1%) vs f/c 30.4%.
ITV studios – sales £1237m (+33% vs 9M +28%) vs f/c £1208m. Adj EBITA £206m vs f/c £207m at a 16.7% margin vs forecast 17.2%.

BE

And Citi, if you want. None of which explains why we're down.

BE

Citi's Take

ITV FY15 revenue and EBITA came in c.1% ahead of consensus, with 4Q NAR of 4.3% a touch ahead of consensus’ 4%. There are two points of focus for the market: 1) A significant special dividend of 10p per share, which drives a 6.5% yield overall (consensus had not assumed a special in their base case); 2) NAR guidance of flat for 1Q may be disappointing, although the group expects positive growth in 2Q and to outperform the TV ad market again this year. On a 2 year rolling rate, flat NAR in 1Q implies c.5.5% NAR for FY16E (assuming underlying trends remain consistent). Consensus forecasts 3.7% NAR, and at this stage in the year this assumption is unlikely to change. We rate ITV Buy.

Revenue & EBITA Beat c.1%

ITV has reported FY15 revenue of £2972m which is 1.4% ahead of consensus/0.8% ahead of Citi. Within this Broadcast & Online came in broadly in line with expectations and Studios 5.7% ahead. NAR of 5.6% for FY15E implies 4.3% in 4Q vs. consensus 4%. EBITA of £865m is 0.6% ahead of consensus and adjusted EPS of 16.5p is 2.5%/1.9% ahead of consensus/Citi.

Focus #1: Special Dividend Well Ahead of Expectations

ITV has announced an ordinary dividend of 6p (consensus 5.7p) and a special dividend of 10p (Citi 3.5p; consensus had not assumed it in the base case). This equates to a 6.5% yield. With the net debt at £319m (15% lower than Citi) at year end, it leaves leverage c.0.8x adjusted for the special dividend.

Focus #2: Flat NAR Guidance for 1Q But Outperformance of Ad Market for FY16

ITV is guiding to flat NAR in 1Q (Jan -1%, Feb -4%, March +5%) and April -4%, but 2Q NAR is expected to be positive as Easter timing, Euro Cup and comps (toughest comp in 1Q) impacts the phasing of NAR for ITV. The group still expects to outperform the TV ad market across 2016. Consensus is forecasting 3.7% NAR for FY16E. Based on the 2 year rolling rate, if the underlying trend remains then flat NAR in 1Q implies 5.5% NAR for FY16E

11:35 am
BE

Focus #3

On Screen Performance Positive YTD – In FY15 ITV family SOV was down 3% and SOCI down 4%. On screen performance has been a concern for investors, and YTD ITV SOV is up 5% and ITV Family SOV is up 2%. This is the best start to a year in some time.

Implications

We expect consensus expectations to remain broadly unchanged at this stage, although we still believe that consensus NAR could see upwards pressure into 2Q based on the 2 year rolling rate of growth.

BE

(@dasv: yep, possibly.)

BE

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily this.

11:36 am
PM

(David's wandered off to make a call. btw)

BE

In terms of what's been mentioned on the right .....

BE

There's the Darty counterbid. Overnight and out of leftfield.

11:37 am
PM

Yeah, full on battle looming here

PM

With south african interest

BE

Clean scoop overnight by Adam Thomson, our man in Paris, along with Arash and Mark VV.

11:38 am
BE

http://www.ft.com/...lls-bid-for-darty/

BE

And the feeling on the sellside is that Steihoff's done enough here.

PM

(Steinhoff now frankfurt listed? -- moved from JoBerg)

11:39 am
PM

(Jo Burg to Frankfurt not a natural move, to my mind)

PM

Here's a quick par from Liberum

PM

Steinhoff has made an approach for Darty for a possible offer of 125 pence per share all in cash. This potential offer is 9% higher than the current Fnac offer, is cleaner being all in cash and represents a better, though not full, valuation for Darty shareholders. It appears that interest in Darty is on the rise which does not surprise us due to the strategic value of the Darty business. We maintain our TP of 160p, BUY

11:39 am
PM

Steinhoff acquired Conforama in 2011, from France’s PPR group for €1.2bn and had revenues last year of €3.23bn. The company has also recently moved its primary listing from Johannesburg to Frankfurt as it attempts to raise it’s profile among European investors. Moreover we feel this move is much more strategic in an attempt to internationalise the group and move away from its domestic currency. The security provided from European assets particularly those with higher and dominant market shares in their key markets and segments will be seen as a key priority away from the volatility and uncertainty in its domestic South African market. This strategy may well mean that a price north of 125 pence may well be achievable.

A potential offer of 125pence per share equates to an equity value of £660m and is comfortably funded from Steinhoff’s £1.7bn cash pile as at June 2015.

As at 30 June 2015, Conforama operated a network of 280 retail outlets, of which 204 are located in France, making it France’s second-largest furniture and household goods retailer by market share.1 In addition, Conforama has leading market positions1 in Switzerland (2nd), Iberica (3rd), Italy (4th) and Croatia (3rd). As at 30 June 2015 Conforama operated 76 retail outlets located in seven other European countries: 30 in Spain and Portugal, 15 in Italy, 22 in Switzerland, seven in Croatia, one in Luxembourg and one in Serbia.

BE

Exane too.

BE

Darty is currently subject to a bid from another French electrical retailer, FNAC, which is under competition commission review. The bid price values Darty at c.11x cal-16 EBIT, or c.7x assuming Steinhoff can achieve a similar level of synergies to that outlined by FNAC. This would imply the deal would be c.2-3% accretive to Steinhoff shareholders. With Steinhoff's cash offer at a c.9% premium to FNAC's equity offer, they are likely to be successful with their bid.

11:40 am
BE

Bid rationale
Another step in Steinhoff's seeming consolidation of European retail. Whilst the focus of Steinhoff isn't in electricals, it does account for c.50% of its French retail asset Conforama. FNAC had outlined c.EUR 85m of synergies arising from buying gains (50%) and back office consolidation (50%). Given their greater overall scale (and similar scale in electricals), we would expect Steinhoff can achieve at least this same level of synergies by integrating Darty with its French retailing business Conforama. Alongside justifying the acquisition (implying a post acquisition synergy multiple of c.7x), in acquiring Darty, Steinhoff prevents the merger of its two largest competitors, spreads its retail footprint which can be leveraged across the brands, and obtains know-how in areas such as online that can be leveraged across the rest of the Group.

BE

Bid in context
Steinhoff now has two all cash bids on the table. Combined the c.EUR2.4bn cost can be absorbed on the balance sheet (raising ND:EBITDA from c.1x to c.2.6x). In both instances Steinhoff is looking to support its current retailing offer whilst also acting as the consolidator rather than let others consolidate around it. In both cases synergies are likely to drive sufficient returns on the acquisition, and have strategic value beyond this. In this instance, the Darty acquisition would look to be c.2-3% accretive to Steinhoff shareholders assuming a similar level of synergies to those outlined by FNAC (coincidentally a similar level of accretion to that we believe is implied in the bid for Home Retail). With a strong track record of sales and margin progress from a litany of M&A, we see this as another positive step in the growth of Steinhoff.

BE

Who'd have predicted Darty would be a strategic asset when Comet was going into administration?

11:42 am
BE

Demerger was, what, 2012?

PM

not sure

BE

Anyway, that's that noted.

11:42 am
undefined
BE

(@nichoman: yes, I'd suggest that's a very sensible way to read it.)

BE

Still on results, we have Intertek mentioned.

11:44 am
Intertek Group PLC (ITRK:LSE): Last: 2,871, down 133 (-4.43%), High: 3,015, Low: 2,869, Volume: 317.16k
BE

Another one that rallied hard into results.

BE

Which are decent, but that's not unexpected post reasonable numbers from Bureau Veritas and SGS.

11:45 am
BE

Intertek's the last of the big three testers to report so it can rarely spring much of a surprise.

BE

More importantly, I guess, there's nothing from the newish CEO on strategy.

BE

Here's Deutsche.

11:46 am
BE

Intertek reported FY15 revenue of £2166m (organic 1.6%, reported 3.5%) vs. company consensus of £2,152m. EBITA was £343m (cons. £339m) up a reported 5.9% and up 4.0% at constant currency. EPS came in at 140.7p (cons 135.1p) up a reported 6.5% YonY and DPS was 52.3p up 6.5% YonY.
Organic growth for the year came in at 1.6% (cons +1.2%). At the 10m stage it was at +1.2%. For 2016 consensus is expecting +2.2%. The company outlook is for solid growth (possibly 1.5% to 2.0%) with a mid single digit outlook for the product and trade related businesses (90% of EBITA) and further softness in oil and gas capex and opex, where the outlook is a little softer than in November.
The FY EBITA margin of 15.9% was up by 40ps and 20bps in constant currency (H1+60bps and 30bps in constant currency). Company guidance is for stable margin (consensus 15.7%).
Operating cash flow was up 15% and FCF up 27% YonY (including FX benefit and better working capital possibly aided by weak O&G). The balance sheet closed the year at 1.7x Net Debt to EBITDA.

BE

In H2 the company saw slower growth in Consumer (3.3%) and Chemical and Pharma (6.8%) than in H1. The company saw slower growth in H2 in the Commodities business (2.7%) and an improvement in the Commercial and Electrical business (6.8%) Industry and Assurance saw a continued decline (-5.3% in H2 vs. -6.3% in H1). The H2 Consumer margin was strong (35.2% +50bps) against a very strong comparator, C&E (+90bps), Commodities (+140bps) were also strong. Industry and Assurance was down by 230bps in H2 (H1 – 290bps)

BE

We expect that consensus 16e EPS may edge up driven by FX. The organic growth outlook is a touch softer than consensus and the stable margin guidance implies some improvement outside of Industry and weakness in it. In the long run we believe the strong management team will generate operational efficiencies that will improve returns, will push internal benchmarking and cross selling to drive growth and will improve the mix through acquisitions. The share has been so strong into results that the slightly softer organic outlook means the stock is unlikely to see further re-rating today. Intertek trades on 20x 16e P/E, 15x EV/EBITA and 3.9% FCF yield, remains Hold.

11:47 am
BE

Barclays reckons the outlook's "possibly a little conservative"

BE

Which given Intertek's exposure to oil and rocks, that's not really a surprise surely?

BE

Intertek is guiding to a “solid organic growth performance” in 2016 – we take this to mean 1.5-2.0% (we model +2%), with flat margins (assuming last 6-mth average FX rates) – in line. Interest costs at around £30m are a little lower than our forecast of £33m and tax is seen at around 25-26% (inline).

11:48 am
BE

The shares trade on c19.5x 2016e PE, falling to c18x in 2017e with a c4.7% FCF yield and c2% dividend yield.

PM

(Dorset -- im afraid he's wandered off. But yes it is the real David McWilliams http://globalmacro360.com/ )

undefined
11:48 am
BE

While doing grey, want a Pearson downgrade?

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 856.50, down 14 (-1.61%), High: 862.00, Low: 846.00, Volume: 1.28m
PM

Oh yes please (tho i closed our short)

11:49 am
BE

(Unilaterally.)

PM

(Couldnt withstand the 6.5% yeild)

BE

Goldman's not convinced.

11:49 am
BE

While we believe that Education remains an attractive long-term market, we
expect structural headwinds to persist and are cautious on Pearson’s ability
to execute on its 2018 operating profit goals. In our view, its expectation
that it can improve operating profit to £800 mn in 2018 is unrealistic and we
expect it to achieve only £740 mn. Furthermore, we believe that the focus
on internal restructuring may be at the expense of staying ahead of both
new and existing competition, at a time of rapid change with lower barriers
to entry for new players, amid disintermediation and democratization which
is eroding historical scale advantages.

BE

Not a believer in jam tomorrow. And when I say tomorrow, I mean the tomorrow that's 750 or so days away.

BE

In our view, Pearson will be unable to reach its 2018 guidance which we
expect to drive negative consensus earnings momentum and sentiment.
Nearer term, we believe that a continuation of weak US higher education
enrolment trends will weigh on hopes for growth for the company. Our
estimate for 2018 EBITA is 7% below the company’s guided 2018 level (our
estimates are reduced to reflect the weaker structural outlook and the failure
for enrolments to pick up again in the US).

11:51 am
BE

Our 12-month price target of 800p (from 870p) is derived from a target P/E
of 13x, applied to CY18E earnings (unchanged i.e., normalised following
restructuring), discounted back one year for consistency, implying a 2017E
multiple of 14.3x and 7% downside vs. 14% upside for our coverage.
Pearson currently trades on 13.1x 2018E P/E, broadly in line with the
professional publishers’ average of 13.6x. However, we believe that given
the uncertain market outlook for Pearson, a discount vs. history is justified.

BE

No argument with all of that.

undefined
11:52 am
PM

ECB meeting next week

PM

Previews starting to arrive

PM

There's is rather gloomy -- from Credit Suisse

11:52 am
PM

Peter Foley

PM

Neville Hill

PM

Close to the edge

11:53 am
PM

The euro's survival over the next few years is levered to the outlook for
growth. If recovery is sustained then major risks to the euro's sustainability –
politics and the banking sector – should diminish. But if the economy slips
back into recession, those risks could swiftly materialise.

PM

So the recent deterioration in cyclical indicators and spike in financial stress
concern us. Near-term downside risks to growth are intensifying from a more
challenging external environment and renewed stress in the financial sector.
The stakes for next week's ECB meeting are high. It remains our view that the
ECB will boost quantitative and credit easing, rather than deliver large cuts in
the deposit rate. We think the more urgent aim for the ECB is not for a lower
euro, but for higher financial asset prices, especially those related to banks

PM

The feedback between the euro area's economy and its financial system is
critical. The past year has seen a virtuous cycle emerge between bank lending
conditions and stronger domestic demand. Financial stress could make that
cycle a vicious one.
For all the focus on the risks from negative interest rates, at the top down level,
there's as yet little evidence of banks' net interest earnings worsening. A
bigger issue may be banks' loan books. Non-performing loans are correlated
with economic performance, and so look set to improve. But a downturn could
deliver the opposite.
The risks are that the euro area shifts from a virtuous to a vicious cycle. In our
view, that urgently makes the need for compelling ECB action next month.

11:53 am

PM

BE

For H2 CY15 versus H2 CY14, Rio Tinto has been the most defensive of the big four, with a 56% decline in its EBIT. Overall, Glencore was the second most defensive, with a 75% decline in its group EBIT. However, the 135% decline in its industrial assets EBIT was materially offset by a 9% increase in its marketing EBIT. This highlights the stability that Glencore’s marketing business brings in an environment where its more traditional mining assets are losing money. Anglo experienced an 83% decline in its H2 CY15 EBIT and BHP Billiton was the worst impacted of this group, with an 84% decline.

BE

Rio, BHP and Anglo demonstrated some genuine cost cutting in H2 CY15. Lower production costs added 14% to Rio’s EBIT, 2% to BHP’s EBIT and 1% to Anglo’s. Excluding the negative impact of higher depreciation, higher cash costs would have removed 4% from Glencore’s industrial assets EBIT in H2 CY15. What stands out in the more recent past is that the companies have been achieving some all-in positive cost driver performances. This implies genuine, all-in cost cutting from the mining industry. Although not consistently last every half, we would suggest that overall Anglo has been the laggard of the big 4 on this measure over time.

BE

What H2 CY15 highlights is that these stocks have been all about US$ commodity prices and the partly off-setting currency moves. While the cost cutting is commendable, in reality this mostly just offsets the usual ravages of uncontrollable cost inflation. We see it as a survival tactic rather than an outright earnings driver. Volumes have bordered on irrelevance in H2 CY15 other than Anglo stockpiling diamonds.

BE

In this note we examine the high quality longwall assets that Anglo American
has put up for sale in Australia and potential buyers. These coal assets form
the most valuable part of the disposal programme, but are in a commodity that
few are excited to enter. Achieving an acceptable valuation for shareholders
may prove challenging. We think the two logical buyers are BHP and Rio. Both
can extract operating synergies, BHP more though. We also think Japanese
trading house, private equity, South32 and X2 may take a look.

12:01 pm
BE

We believe from BHP’s standpoint, the acquisition of Anglo’s coal assets
would provide operational synergies around Goonyella and Caval Ridge, plus
best practice opportunities which could unlock material value for
Broadmeadow. But the company has made it clear that its preferred areas of
investment are copper and oil. In addition, regulators are likely to investigate
any acquisition by BHP. Rio Tinto has expressed interest in met coal
previously, but does it need more exposure to Chinese steel? There may be
synergies with its Kestrel UG mine. But does it want to assist in Anglo’s
balance sheet repair or does it see other assets that may fall from the tree if
the environment deteriorates further? Would the Japanese trading houses, PE,
X2 or S32 have any interest? Based on a long term met coal price of US$125/t
and AUDUSD of 75c our NPV of Grosvenor and Moranbah is US$3.3bn. Every
US$5/t reduction in our LT met coal price curve reduces NPV by US$328m.

BE

Anglo has announced it is shrinking its operations to three core areas and has
effectively put “the for sale sign up” on all remaining assets. It has also talked
about debt reduction to US$6bn, suggesting US$7bn of disposals. But in
reality, we expect Anglo to try and sell only a portion of the assets for sale. The
extent of any disposal program beyond the US$3-4bn targeted for 2016 will be
dependent on progress on cost cutting and operational gains as well as
operating cash flow. Investors should focus on progress towards the 2.5x ratio
more than the absolute level of debt reduction, in our opinion. Given the size of
the disposal program (1x current market cap potentially) management will be
under significant pressure to limit the value destruction on any single disposal
by their owners- the shareholders.

BE

The underlying value of Anglo’s assets remains materially in excess of the
current share price. However, execution risk around the disposal program
remains high making any investment case difficult without signs of progress
on delivery. Main risks include higher/lower commodity prices,
stronger/weaker FX and progress or delays on the disposal program.

12:03 pm
BE

South32 has exceeded the market's expectations on costs and is on track to deliver a FCF yield greater than 10% on a flat commodity deck. Top down, positive developments include supply curtailments in manganese and a slowing decline in Chinese thermal coal imports. But the structural drivers of weak alumina, manganese and thermal coal prices remain and deflation is likely to continue. After a greater than 50% increase in its share price since December on flat EM we downgrade to SELL with our 50p PT set at a 25% discount to NPV.
